content.title: Acute Appendicitis
content.summary: Acute appendicitis is the most common surgical emergency, caused by obstruction and subsequent inflammation of the vermiform appendix. Classic presentation includes periumbilical pain migrating to the right lower quadrant, accompanied by anorexia, nausea, and fever. Diagnosis relies on clinical assessment, inflammatory markers, and imaging (CT preferred in adults, ultrasound in children/pregnant).
key_points: Most common cause of acute surgical abdomen; lifetime risk 7-8%
Classic history: Periumbilical pain → RLQ (McBurney's point) over 12-24 hours
Physical exam: RLQ tenderness, guarding, positive Rovsing's, psoas, obturator signs
CT with IV contrast: 94% sensitivity, 95% specificity in adults
Treatment: Appendectomy (laparoscopic preferred); antibiotics alone in select uncomplicated cases
Perforation risk increases after 36-48 hours of symptom onset
content.statement: Acute appendicitis is diagnosed through classic history of migrating abdominal pain with RLQ tenderness, supported by imaging confirmation, and managed primarily with appendectomy to prevent perforation and complications.

explanation.intuition: Think of the appendix as a blind-ended tube that can get blocked like a clogged drain. Once blocked (by a fecalith or lymphoid hyperplasia), bacteria overgrow, the wall swells, blood supply is compromised, and eventually the appendix bursts. The pain starts vague and central (visceral) then localizes to RLQ (somatic) as the inflammation touches the parietal peritoneum.
explanation.key_insight: The MIGRATION of pain from periumbilical to RLQ is KEY to diagnosis. Initial visceral pain is referred to the periumbilical area (T10 dermatome). As inflammation extends to involve the parietal peritoneum overlying the appendix, pain localizes precisely to McBurney's point. Atypical presentations (retrocecal, pelvic appendix) may alter location.
explanation.technical_details: Luminal obstruction → mucus accumulation → bacterial overgrowth → mucosal ischemia → transmural inflammation → perforation. Alvarado score (MANTRELS: Migration, Anorexia, Nausea, Tenderness RLQ, Rebound, Elevated temp, Leukocytosis, Shift left) helps risk stratify. Score ≥7 suggests appendicitis.

definitions_glossary.acute_appendicitis: Inflammation of the vermiform appendix, typically from luminal obstruction
definitions_glossary.fecalith: Calcified fecal matter (appendicolith) causing appendiceal obstruction
definitions_glossary.McBurney_point: Point 1/3 distance from ASIS to umbilicus; classic location of RLQ tenderness
definitions_glossary.Rovsing_sign: RLQ pain elicited by palpation of LLQ; suggests peritoneal irritation
definitions_glossary.psoas_sign: RLQ pain with passive hip extension; suggests retrocecal appendix
definitions_glossary.obturator_sign: RLQ pain with internal rotation of flexed right hip; suggests pelvic appendix
definitions_glossary.guarding: Involuntary abdominal muscle contraction indicating peritoneal irritation
definitions_glossary.rebound_tenderness: Pain on sudden release of pressure; indicates peritoneal inflammation
definitions_glossary.perforation: Appendiceal wall rupture leading to peritonitis or abscess
definitions_glossary.appendicolith: Radio-opaque calcified material seen in 10-15% on imaging
definitions_glossary.Alvarado_score: Clinical scoring system to risk-stratify suspected appendicitis

pathophysiology.mechanism: Luminal obstruction (fecalith, lymphoid hyperplasia, tumor) → intraluminal pressure increase → venous congestion → bacterial invasion → transmural inflammation → necrosis → perforation

atypical_positions.retrocecal: Flank/back pain, psoas sign positive, missed on anterior exam
atypical_positions.pelvic: Suprapubic pain, urinary symptoms, obturator sign positive

clinical_presentation: Periumbilical pain migrating to RLQ over 12-24 hours
laboratory_findings: Urinalysis: mild pyuria/hematuria possible (irritation, not UTI)

imaging.CT_abdomen: Adults: IV contrast preferred; >6mm appendix, wall enhancement, periappendiceal fat stranding

surgical.laparoscopic_appendectomy: Preferred approach; lower wound infection, faster recovery
surgical.open_appendectomy: For complicated cases, unclear anatomy, or surgeon preference

non_operative.antibiotics_alone: Select uncomplicated cases (no fecalith, no perforation); 70% success but 30% recurrence
non_operative.indications: Patient preference, high surgical risk, early uncomplicated presentation

complicated_appendicitis.abscess: Percutaneous drainage + antibiotics; interval appendectomy in 6-8 weeks
complicated_appendicitis.phlegmon: IV antibiotics; surgery if fails to improve

antibiotics.duration: Uncomplicated: single dose; Complicated: 3-5 days post-op

definition.@value: Acute inflammation of the vermiform appendix, typically caused by luminal obstruction, presenting with migratory RLQ pain and treated primarily with appendectomy

scopeNote.@value: Covers pathophysiology, diagnosis, imaging, and treatment of acute appendicitis

learning_objectives: Describe the classic presentation of acute appendicitis including pain migration
Perform physical examination maneuvers (Rovsing's, psoas, obturator signs)
Select appropriate imaging based on patient population
Compare surgical vs non-operative management strategies
clinical_pearls: Anorexia almost always present - consider alternative diagnosis if hungry
Perforation risk increases significantly after 36-48 hours of symptoms
Get pregnancy test in ALL reproductive-age women with RLQ pain
Retrocecal appendix may have minimal anterior tenderness - psoas sign key
Antibiotics alone: 70% success but 30% recurrence within 5 years
common_misconceptions: High WBC is required - may be normal early in course
Surgery is always needed - antibiotics alone is an option in select cases
CT is always needed - clinical diagnosis may suffice in classic presentations
